author: William Shakespeare
summary: A comedic play that tells the story of Helena's pursuit of Bertram, the man she loves.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black

COUNTESS:
In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband.

BERTRAM:
And I in going, madam, weep o'er my father's death anew:

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragic play that explores the relationship between the Roman general Mark Antony and the Egyptian queen Cleopatra.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Alexandria. A room in CLEOPATRA's palace.

Enter DEMETRIUS and PHILO

PHILO:
Nay, but this dotage of our general's
O'erflows the measure: those his goodly eyes,
That o'er the files and musters of the war
Have glow'd like plated Mars,

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A pastoral comedy centered around love, mistaken identities, and the Forest of Arden.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Orchard of Oliver's house.

Enter ORLANDO and ADAM

ORLANDO:
As I remember, Adam, it was upon this fashion
bequeathed me by will but poor a thousand crowns,
and, as thou sayest, charged my brother on his blessing
to breed me well: and

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A farcical comedy of mistaken identity involving two sets of twins separated at birth.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. A hall in DUKE SOLINUS'S palace.

Enter DUKE SOLINUS, AEGEON, Gaoler, Officers, and other Attendants

AEGEON:
Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall
And by the doom of death end woes and all.

DUKE SOLINUS:
Merchant of Syracuse, plead no more;

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragedy based on the life of the Roman leader Caius Marcius Coriolanus.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Rome. A street.

Enter a company of mutinous Citizens, with staves, clubs, and other weapons

First Citizen:
Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

All:
Speak, speak!

First Citizen:
You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A complex play involving mistaken identities, a wicked stepmother, and a lost princess.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Britain. The garden of Cymbeline's palace.

Enter two Gentlemen

First Gentleman:
You do not meet a man but frowns: our bloods
No more obey the heavens than our courtiers
Still seem as does the king.

Second Gentleman:
But what's the matter?

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragedy about the Prince of Denmark seeking revenge for his father's death.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Elsinore. A platform before the castle.

Enter FRANCISCO and BERNARDO, two sentinels

BERNARDO:
Who's there?
FRANCISCO:
Nay, answer me: stand, and

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A historical play that explores the conflict between Prince Hal and Hotspur, set during the reign of King Henry IV.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. London. The palace.

Enter KING HENRY, LORD JOHN OF LANCASTER, the EARL of WESTMORELAND, SIR WALTER BLUNT, and others

KING HENRY:
So shaken as we are, so wan with care,
Find we a time for frighted peace to pant,

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A continuation of the story from Henry IV, Part 1, focusing on the events leading up to the death of King Henry IV.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Westminster. The palace.

Enter KING HENRY, LORD JOHN OF LANCASTER, the EARL of WESTMORELAND, SIR WALTER BLUNT, and others

KING HENRY:
So shaken as we are, so wan with care,
Find we a time for frighted peace to pant,

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A history play that follows the events of King Henry V's military campaigns in France.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. London. An ante-chamber in the KING's palace.

Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY and the BISHOP OF ELY

CANTERBURY:
My lord, I'll tell you; that self bill is urged,
Which in the eleventh year of the last king's reign
Was

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A historical play that depicts the early reign of King Henry VI and the conflict between England and France.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Westminster Abbey.

Dead March. Enter the Funeral of KING HENRY the Fifth, attended on by Dukes of BEDFORD, Regent of France; GLOUCESTER, Protector; and EXETER, Earl of WARWICK, the BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, Heralds, & c

BEDFORD:
Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to night!
Comets,

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A historical play that continues the story of King Henry VI, focusing on the power struggle between the houses of Lancaster and York.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. London. The palace.

Enter the Duke of GLOUCESTER, solus

GLOUCESTER:
Now is the winter of our discontent
Made glorious summer by this sun of York;
And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A historical play that concludes the story of King Henry VI, showcasing the Wars of the Roses and the rise of Richard III to power.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. London. The palace.

Flourish of trumpets: then hautboys. Enter KING HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, SALISBURY, WARWICK, and CARDINAL, on the one side; QUEEN MARGARET, SUFFOLK, YORK, SOMERSET, and BUCKINGHAM, on the other

SUFFOLK:
As by your high imperial majesty

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A history play that depicts the events surrounding the reign of King Henry VIII and his relationships with his wives.
text:
PROLOGUE

I come no more to make you laugh: things now,
That bear a weighty and a serious brow,
Sad, high, and working, full of state and woe,
Such noble scenes as draw the eye to flow,
We now present. Those that can pity, here

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragedy that portrays the conspiracy against and assassination of Roman dictator Julius Caesar.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Rome. A street.

Enter FLAVIUS, MARULLUS, and certain Commoners

FLAVIUS:
Hence! home, you idle creatures get you home:
Is this a holiday? What! know you not,
Being mechanical, you ought not walk

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A history play that depicts the conflict between King John of England and his nobles, as well as his interactions with other European rulers.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. King John's palace.

Enter KING JOHN, QUEEN ELINOR, PEMBROKE, ESSEX, SALISBURY, and others, with CHATILLON

KING JOHN:
Now, say, Chatillon, what would France with us?
CHATILLON:
Thus, after greeting, speaks the King of France

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragedy that depicts the gradual descent into madness of King Lear, as he divides his kingdom among his daughters.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. King Lear's palace.

Enter KENT, GLOUCESTER, and EDMUND

KENT:
I thought the king had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall.
GLOUCESTER:
It did always seem so to us: but now, in the division of the kingdom,

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A comedy that revolves around the King of Navarre and his companions' vow to avoid romantic entanglements, which is challenged when the Princess of France arrives.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. The king of Navarre's park.

Enter FERDINAND king of Navarre, BIRON, LONGAVILLE, and DUMAIN

FERDINAND:
Let fame, that all hunt after in their lives,
Live register'd upon our brazen tombs
And then grace us in the disgrace of death;
When,

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragedy that tells the story of Macbeth, a Scottish general who becomes consumed by his ambition for power and descends into madness.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. A desert place.

Thunder and lightning. Enter three Witches

First Witch:
When shall we three meet again
In thunder, lightning, or in rain?
Second Witch:
When the hurlyburly's done,
When the battle's lost and won.

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A dark comedy that explores themes of justice, mercy, and hypocrisy through the story of a young nun who pleads for her brother's life.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. An apartment in the Duke's palace.

Enter DUKE VINCENTIO, ESCALUS, Lords, and Attendants

DUKE VINCENTIO:
Escalus!
ESCALUS:
My lord?
DUKE VINCENTIO:
Of government the properties to unfold

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragicomedy that revolves around a merchant in Venice who borrows money from a Jewish moneylender, Shylock, and the consequences that follow.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Venice. A street.

Enter ANTONIO, SALARINO, and SALANIO

ANTONIO:
In sooth, I know not why I am so sad:
It wearies me; you say it wearies you;
But how I

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A comedy that follows the misadventures of Sir John Falstaff as he attempts to seduce two married women, Mistress Ford and Mistress Page, for financial gain.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Windsor. Before PAGE's house.

Enter JUSTICE SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS

SHALLOW:
Sir Hugh, persuade me not; I will make a Star-chamber matter of it: if he were twenty Sir

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A romantic comedy that portrays the events surrounding the marriage of Theseus, the Duke of Athens, and Hippolyta, the Queen of the Amazons, as well as the adventures of four young lovers and a group of amateur actors.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.

Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, and Attendants

THESEUS:
Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour
Draws on apace; four happy days bring in
Another moon:

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A comedy that explores themes of love, deception, and mistaken identity through the story of two couples: Benedick and Beatrice, and Claudio and Hero.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Before LEONATO'S house.

Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger

LEONATO:
I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon
comes this night to Messina.

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragedy that delves into themes of jealousy, manipulation, and racism, as it follows the story of Othello, a Moorish general in the Venetian army, and his downfall orchestrated by his ensign, Iago.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Venice. A street.

Enter RODERIGO and IAGO

RODERIGO:
Tush! never tell me; I take it much unkindly
That thou, Iago, who hast had my purse

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A romance that follows the journey of Pericles, Prince of Tyre, as he faces various trials and adventures in his quest for love, reunion, and redemption.
text:
PROLOGUE

Enter GOWER

GOWER:
To sing a song that old was sung,
From ashes ancient Gower is come;
Assuming man's infirmities,
To glad your ear, and please your eyes.

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A historical play that depicts the downfall of King Richard II and the rise of Henry Bolingbroke, who later becomes Henry IV.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. London. KING RICHARD II's palace.

Enter KING RICHARD II, JOHN OF GAUNT, with other Nobles and Attendants

KING RICHARD II:
Old John of Gaunt, time-honour'd Lancaster,
Hast thou, according to thy oath

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A historical play that portrays the rise and fall of Richard III, the power-hungry Duke of Gloucester, as he manipulates his way to the throne of England.
text:

Scene 1. London. A street.

Enter GLOUCESTER, solus

GLOUCESTER:
Now is the winter of our discontent
Made glorious summer by this sun of York;
And all the clouds that

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragic love story about two young star-crossed lovers, Romeo and Juliet, from feuding families, who defy their circumstances and choose to be together, ultimately leading to their untimely deaths.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Verona. A public place.

Enter SAMPSON and GREGORY, of the house of Capulet, armed with swords and bucklers

SAMPSON:
Gregory, on my word, we'll not carry

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A comedy that explores themes of gender roles and societal expectations through the courtship of Petruchio and Katherine, a headstrong and independent woman.
text:
SCENE I. Before an alehouse on a heath.

Enter Hostess and SLY

SLY:
I'll pheeze you, in faith.

Hostess:
A pair of stocks, you rogue!

SLY:
Y'are a baggage: the Slys are

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A romantic comedy set on a remote island, where Prospero, a sorcerer and rightful Duke of Milan, uses his magical powers to orchestrate a series of events that lead to reconciliation, forgiveness, and love.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. On a ship at sea. A tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard.

Enter a Master and a Boatswain

MASTER:
Boatswain!
BOATSWAIN:
Here, master: what cheer?
MASTER:
Good, speak to the mariners:

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragic play that follows the story of Timon, a wealthy and generous nobleman, who is betrayed by his friends and descends into misanthropy and ruin.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.

Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors

POET:
Good day, sir.
PAINTER:
I am glad y'are well.
POET:
I have

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A bloody tragedy that tells the story of Titus Andronicus, a Roman general, and his descent into revenge and madness after the brutal rape and mutilation of his daughter.
text:

Scene 1. Rome. Before the Capitol.

The Tomb of the ANDRONICI appearing; the Tribunes and Senators aloft. Enter, below, from one side, SATURNINUS and his

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragicomedy set during the Trojan War, exploring themes of love, honor, and the futility of war through the doomed romance of Troilus, a Trojan prince, and Cressida, a Trojan captive.
text:

Enter NESTOR, ULYSSES, and TROILUS, dressed like rustics

ULYSSES:
Now, princes, for the service I have done you,
The advantage of the time prompts me

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A romantic comedy that follows the story of Viola, who disguises herself as a man and becomes entangled in a web of mistaken identity and love triangles in the kingdom of Illyria.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. DUKE ORSINO's palace.

Enter DUKE ORSINO, CURIO, and other Lords; Musicians attending

DUKE ORSINO:
If music be the food of love, play on;
Give me

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A comedy that explores the themes of friendship, loyalty, and love, as two best friends, Valentine and Proteus, find themselves entangled in a complex web of romance and deception.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Verona. An open place.

Enter VALENTINE and PROTEUS

VALENTINE:
Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus:
Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.
Were't not, affection

author: William Shakespeare
summary: A tragicomedy that tells the story of Leontes, a jealous king who accuses his wife Hermione of infidelity, resulting in tragic consequences and the eventual redemption and reconciliation of the characters.
text:
ACT I

Scene 1. Antechamber in Leontes' palace.

Enter CAMILLO and ARCHIDAMUS

ARCHIDAMUS:
If you shall chance, Camillo, to visit Bohemia, on the
like occasion whereon my services
